I agree that Smalltalk is a much better language for learning (and
implementing) objects. It pains me to see Java held up as an example of
a great OO language, without any acknowledgement of Smalltalk. For the
last three years, I've spent approximately 50% of each day using Java
and 50% using Smalltalk and I'm much more productive when using
Smalltalk. That said, it would be nice if Smalltalk supported
Interfaces, which I find extremely useful but is not yet supported in
Smalltalk, to my knowledge.

You can also download a free, noncommercial version of VisualWorks,
which is an industrial-strength version of Smalltalk that's been proven
in a number of industries (financial, industrial, shipping, etc.) for
years at
http://www.cincom.com/scripts/smalltalk.dll//downloads/index.ssp

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...] 
> 
> 
> <disclaimer>
> 	What follows is a shameless plug for a real Object-Oriented
> 	language, one that is much better than the knock-off Java
> 	that many of us are forced to program in on a regular 
> basis. </disclaimer>
> 
> If you are *really* interested in a language that will help 
> you to understand Objects better than any language out there, 
> Smalltalk is the way to go.  That being said the flavor of 
> the day is definitely Squeak, an open source implementation 
> of the Smalltalk-80 system (www.squeak.org
> -- a minimal front-end to the community).  As far as IDEs go, 
> Smalltalk was and continues to be the leader for many 
> reasons, but since this isn't a Smalltalk list, I will leave 
> it there to whet your appetite.  By the way, in case you 
> didn't know, JUnit is the Java equivalent of the original 
> XUnit testing framework by Kent Beck called SUnit (Smalltalk 
> Unit), and Squeak is fully up-to-date with the latest and 
> greatest on that front as well.
> 
> =jason
